title: A Multi-Agent Approach to Dermatology Assistance
author: Radiant Group
excerpt: How Radiant combined vision, retrieval, and reasoning agents for dermatological support.
content:
## Context
Dermatology combines visual perception, medical knowledge, and patient communication. Each dimension introduces distinct challenges.

Single-model approaches struggle to handle this complexity reliably.

## Problem Statement
End-to-end systems conflate perception, reasoning, and explanation. When errors occur, it is difficult to localize responsibility.

## Design Principles
- Agent specialization
- Explicit information flow
- Evidence grounding

## System Overview
The system is composed of multiple agents: a vision agent for lesion detection, a retrieval agent for medical knowledge, and a synthesis agent for structured output generation.

Each agent operates within a clearly defined scope.

## Technical Choices
Medical knowledge is retrieved explicitly rather than embedded implicitly. This reduces hallucinations and improves traceability.

Agent boundaries enable independent evaluation and safer iteration.

## Evaluation
Each agent is evaluated separately using task-appropriate metrics. Failures are localized and analyzable.

## Limitations
The system does not provide diagnoses. It supports orientation and documentation.

## Lessons Learned
Agent-based decomposition aligns better with clinical reasoning than monolithic intelligence.

## Conclusion
Multi-agent architectures improve transparency, safety, and maintainability in medical AI systems.
